sub_topics.title: Drama

teacher_steps: Introduce drama and its elements to the learners and how drama can be performed as provided in the excerpt 'The Price of a Shortcut'
Lead a class discussion on drama and its elements
Consolidate the activity by highlighting key elements: Drama is a genre of literature intended to be performed by actors in front of an audience
learner_steps: Participate in class discussion on drama and its elements
Identify elements of drama including plot, characters, dialogue, conflict, theme, setting, staging, stage directions, symbolism, and irony
Analyze the script 'The Price of a Shortcut' for dramatic elements
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Drama is a genre of literature that is intended to be performed by actors in front of an audience. It can also be experienced through reading scripts. Key elements include: Plot (sequence of events), Characters/Actors (performers), Dialogue (conversations between characters), Conflict (problem driving the plot), Theme (central idea), Setting (time, place, social context), Staging (set design), Stage Directions (instructions for performance), Symbolism (objects/actions representing deeper meaning), and Irony (statements opposite of actual meaning).

teacher_steps: Assign topics to learners on which they can write scripts to be acted in the next lesson
Let the learners present the scripts that they wrote as assigned in the previous lesson
Allow the groups to perform their plays
Consolidate the activity by highlighting performance skills: costume, voice projection, body movement, facial expression, gestures, props, staging, stage directions, and turn-taking
learner_steps: Write scripts on assigned topics (cross-cutting themes: gender, climate change, corruption, governance)
Present and perform plays in groups
Practice costume wearing and character portrayal
Apply voice projection for clarity and audibility
Use body movement including posture, gestures, facial expressions, and gait
Handle props appropriately
Follow stage directions
Practice turn-taking in dialogue
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Performing plays requires specific skills: Costume (clothing and accessories to portray characters), Voice projection (clarity and audibility), Body movement (deliberate physical expression including posture, gestures, facial expression, gait), Facial expression (showing emotions and reactions), Gestures (body movements to communicate meaning and emotions), Properties/Props (objects actors handle on stage), Staging (set design presentation), Stage Directions (playwright's performance instructions), Turn-taking (conversational rhythm in dialogue).

sub_topics.short_notes: Drama is a genre of literature involving serious emotional or thought-provoking narrative presented before an audience. It includes scripts meant for performance and contains essential elements like plot, character, dialogue, setting, conflict, staging, theme, symbolism, and irony. Performance requires skills in costume, voice projection, body movement, facial expression, gestures, use of props, following stage directions, and turn-taking.

sub_topics.title: Poetry

teacher_steps: Introduce poetry and its elements to the learners and how poems can be performed and reviewed as provided in the excerpt 'Zambia is Getting Warmer'
Ask learners to state emotions and ideas on which poems can be based (guide learners on thematic areas of poetry)
Lead a class discussion on what a poem is and its elements
Consolidate the activity by highlighting: Poetry is a form of literature that uses rhythmic and figurative language to express emotions and ideas
learner_steps: Read and analyze the poem 'Zambia is Getting Warmer'
State emotions and ideas on which poems can be based
Participate in class discussion on poetry and its elements
Identify structural elements: form, stanza, line, verse, rhythm, rhyme
Identify poetic devices: mood, imagery, language, tone, alliteration, assonance, consonance, onomatopoeia
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Poetry is a form of literature that uses rhythmic and figurative language to express emotions and ideas. A poem is a literary work that expresses emotions and ideas. Poems are usually Didactic (intended to teach a lesson) or Aesthetic (appreciation of beauty). Structural elements include: Form (structure of the poem), Stanza (division of two or more lines), Line (unit of writing), Verse (collection of lines with metrical rhythm), Rhythm (pattern of stressed/unstressed syllables), Rhyme (repetition of similar sounds). Poetic devices include: Mood, Imagery (descriptive language appealing to senses), Language (poet's word choice including figurative language), Tone (poet's attitude), Alliteration (repetition of initial consonant sounds), Assonance (repetition of vowel sounds), Consonance (repetition of consonant sounds), Onomatopoeia (words that imitate sounds). Narrative poetry includes plot, setting, characters and characterization.

teacher_steps: Play a poem for the learners to listen to
Lead a discussion on how to perform poems on different cross-cutting issues (drug abuse, climate change, corruption, human rights, teenage pregnancies)
Put learners in groups, ask them to perform poems on different cross-cutting issues given in the previous activity
Lead a discussion on reviewing performed poems (Content and meaning, poetic devices and techniques, structure and organisation)
Consolidate the activity by highlighting key aspects of how poems are performed and reviewed
learner_steps: Listen to performed poems
Discuss how to perform poems on cross-cutting issues
Perform poems in groups on topics like drug abuse, climate change, corruption, human rights, teenage pregnancies
Apply vocal delivery techniques
Use gestures and body language
Emphasize poetic devices: imagery, repetition, alliteration, assonance, figurative language
Review performed poems for content, meaning, poetic devices, and structure
instructional_blocks.short_notes: Performing poetry involves bringing a poem to life through vocal expression, movement, and engagement with an audience. Performance focuses on content, meaning, poetic devices and structural organization. Content and Meaning: Often reflects personal experiences, cultural identity, historical themes, or contemporary social issues. Poetic Devices in performance include: Imagery (vivid descriptions engaging senses), Repetition (reinforces key messages and creates rhythm), Alliteration and Assonance (enhance musicality), Figurative Language (adds depth to meaning). Performance poetry involves delivering poetry aloud with emphasis on vocal delivery, gestures and body language to create a dynamic and engaging experience. It combines poetry, storytelling and performance as artistic expression.

sub_topics.short_notes: Poetry is a genre of literature used to express ideas and emotions. It is a form of literature that uses rhythmic and figurative language. Poems can be Didactic (teaching) or Aesthetic (beauty appreciation). Key structural elements include form, stanza, line, verse, rhythm, and rhyme. Poetic devices include mood, imagery, language, tone, alliteration, assonance, consonance, and onomatopoeia. Performance poetry emphasizes vocal delivery, gestures, body language, and engagement with audience, combining poetry, storytelling and performance.
